text:
33 cl bottle.
Pours clear golden color with a large white head. Sweet fruity aroma with caramel and pine notes, mild malts and some herbal tones. Flavor is juicy fruity, bitter malty with caramel notes, slightly grassy. Carbonation is medium, slick palate.
4414

9th Nov 2016: cask half-pint in The Shrewsbury Hotel (Wetherspoons in Shrewsbury). Golden pour, white head. Hops all the way here, piney, citrusy and resiny at the same time. Nice balance of bitterness and hop managemant: liked it.
On cask at JDW pours a slight hazed amber. Nice off white head. Fruity hoppy malt aroma. Bready citrus pine flavours. Marmalade and earthy. Very nice.

Kveldens første på Mi2, Cardinal aug-16: vi begynner med fatøl, uklar gylden med ok skum. Og dette er en frisk og aromatisk start på kvelden - citrus/appelsinmarmelade og tropiske frukter i fin forening. Citra er og blir en av mine favoritthumler, og med de tropiske fruktene fra Amarillo langt fremme i smaksbildet er dette en deilig apa. Fin maltkropp, og noen solbærtoner fra Bramling Cross gjør helhetsinntrykket enda bedre. Vi skåler fornøyd og gleder oss til neste runde!

On tap at Cardinal, Stavanger. Pours hazy amber with little white head. Aroma of tropical fruits, citrus, some pine needles. 
Tastes bitter with little sweetness. Thin bodied, dry mouth feel, bitter finish.

On tap at Cardinal Pub & Bar, Stavanger. Hazy deep golden to orange colour, low white head. Lovely and intense aroma of tropical fruits, also some citrus. The flavour is mid between sweet and dry, tropical fruits and citrus again, pine needles and resin in the medium bitter finish.
-cask- clear golden with stable white head. green, tropical fruit and pine. Dry, hoppy and fruity. Nice.
Cask at the Brewhouse, Staveley. Pours dark orange with a small head. Aroma is acrid bread and orange. Taste orange to start and a bitter bready and marmalade finish.
Cask at the source. Clear golden yellow color, dense white head with solid lacing. Beautiful floral aroma. Taste is earthy, almost dank flowers and summer fruit. Awesome.

Cask in the Hawkshead Beer Hall. Amber with a frothy white head. Really nice tropical aroma with mango especially. The taste has lots mor mango and pineapple over caramel with a slightly dry bitter finish. Good.
Not really sure why this is listed as a ESB, Im taking it as more of an IPA, good hop bitterness, and a nice bitter finish

Keg @ Man in the Moon. Hazy golden, white rich lacing head. Fruity hoppy nose. Medium carbonated, juicy mouthfeel. Tropical fruity taste, citrus zest, passion fruit, grass and hay. Pleasant dry finish with zesty bitterness.

Draught at Man In The Moon, Stockholm. Hazy copper/orange beer with a decent offwhite head. Hoppy fruity aroma, citrus, grass, hay, some caramel. Hoppy citrus flavor, some tropical fruits, citrus, grassy notes. Decent beer.

Bottle @ Welcome back old spice tasting. Small sample. The aroma is flowery, bit citric,light biscuit. Bit hazy, copper coloured beer with a thin, white head. The taste is light bitter, flowery bit toffee and biscuit malt tones, bit citric. Okay.
Pours cloudy amber with thin white head. Aroma is fruit salad and hops. Taste is malty with a hint of coffee.

33cl bottle shared at December THT
Thin white head. Cloudy blond pour. Tropical fruit hoppiness.

Bottle shared at the return of Old Spice tasting. Pours hazy dark golden with a medium white head. Aroma of pissy hops, floral and sweet malt. Flavour is moderate sweet and bitter. Light to medium bodied with light carbonation.
Bottle at THT. Clear golden with white head. Very floral, lychee, lime, very mineral, light chicory. Light bitter, and very light sweetness. Light bodied. Meh.
On tap. Amber whit thin off-white head. Hoppy aroma, sweet malt flavour with bitter finish
Cask at The Euston tap. Poured clear golden with white head. Nose is pine citrus. Taste is slightly fruity citrus wheat straw light malt. Refreshing.

Cask at The Reginald Mitchell, Hanley (JDW) A clear deep golden colour with medium white head. Aroma of grapefruit, orange, melon, slight mango, subtle pineapple, some biscuit and grassy hops. Taste is similar of grapefruit, orange, melon, subtle pineapple, maybe apricot, a little caramel, slight biscuit and grassy hops. Medium bodied and an oily texture. A lingering, dry, crisp, citrus hop bitterness in the finish. A big citrusy, tropical flavour and a refreshingly, crisp bitterness in the finish. A cracking IPA style golden ale.
Cask at Craft Clapham. Pours a gold colour with a thin white head, aroma is all fruit, taste is light bitterness, with a dry finish.

Cask at CBC Clapham, Craft 100, London. It pours a slightly hazy golden color with a small white head. Aroma is crispy and grainy, lightly grassy. Taste is more grains, zest, grass and straw. Light biscuit and light bitterness. Light bodied with soft carbonation. Overall, ok

A 330ml bottle with a best before date of May 2016 and poured into a pint glass. The beer poured a hazy golden orangey colour with a thin weak white head that leaves some stringy lacing. Aromas are fruity and start with melon, pineapple, tangerine and orange with hints of caramel. Taste was a little on the weak side when you consider the amount of fruit in the aroma. Biscuity caramel malt with some citrus mandarin and grapefruit. There are also hints of mango, grass and pine with a long bitter finish. Medium bodied with low to medium carbonation. Overall this was quite good especially the aroma but was hoping that there was more of a punch in the taste considering the nice aromas.
UPDATED: OCT 3, 2016 Golden. Very hoppy aroma. White head. Grassy caramel tangerine taste with citrus bitterness. Good strength. Enjoyable.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ 2015, Olympia, London - fuzzy golden coloured pour with white head. Citrus fruity hoppy aroma and taste, satsuma and lemon, straw, some grassy and floral nuances, refreshing, easy going brew.
Aroma of oranges/tangerines. Initially sweet and fruity with zesty bitterness in aftertaste.
The taste comes through as slightly sweet, possibly as a result of the strength albeit a "golden" ale. For this reason only, I marked it down otherwise not too shabby.

Cask at the brewery. Golden light orange coloured pour with a steadfast smooth off white head. Aroma is caramel / crystal malt with pine needle and tangerine. Flavour is caramel and biscuit malt base slightly spicy pine needle, berry fruit and a bit of pine needle. Palate is semi sweet, moderate carbonation. Little grassy assertive hop bitterness in the finish. Solid IPA.

On cask at Hawkshead Beer Hall, Staveley - Hazy amber body, thin white head. Floral hoppy aroma with grass and hints of tropical fruits. Very floral hop flavour as well, tropical fruits with hints of grassy and traces of pine. Pretty good!

Half pint at Wspoons. First sip is very very promising slightly sweet with depth. Slips into a long bitter finish which lingers a bit too long for me. Almost very nice...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask at the counting house, Glasgow. Pours clear pale gold, thin white head. Aromas of citrus, light orange pith, some sulphur. Taste is light sweet, bitter orange. Sticky texture, thin bitter finish.

Cask at Craft Beer Co, Clerkenwell on 22nd February 2015. Amber with thin off-white head and spot lacing. Rich and intense tangerine and grapefruit aroma with deep malts. Lush grapefruit hop in-mouth with grassy notes. Grassy grapefruit finish with fine bitterness. Light bodied with zingy mouthfeel.

There is an awful lot going on with this, from the citrus/orange/lemon/other aroma, through the lovely color, then a melody of flavours to a dryish finish. Not actually sure Im enjoying it as it is a lot of work, perhaps the fuggles? Who knows I clearly dont.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2015 Keg in the Horseshoe NW3. Orangey amber colour. Served cold. Some fruity hop, sweetish malt. Actually a bit bland and disappointing, especially as Ive really enjoyed hoppy Hawkshead beers before - dont know whether it was the cold keg taking the edge off?

Re-rate at the Spoons by Baker St. Cask. Much better, more aromatic, big citrus grapefruit and some pine bitterness. Malts are sweetish grainy but take a back seat. Long bitter finish, tongue smothering oily hoppiness. Like a different beer from the previous review! Current score an average of 2.9 and 3.7.

bottle, thanks to mowbeer for picking this up at braubeviale. clear orange colour with a modest head; aroma of pineapple upside-down cake, slightly doughy; some tingling citrus, pineapple, grapefruit; lively and very drinkable
Tap. Pour is amber, aroma is strong fruity. Taste is fruity, strong malty backbone, thin body. Nice

Bottle. Beermoth, Manchester. Clear pale amber. A few soap sud type bubbles. Sweet, caramel malt. Some orange. Some syrupy pineapple. Taste is heavy sweet. Palate is dull, thick, and lifeless. Finishes with some oily bitterness. Maybe this is a duff bottle. Not good.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2015 Cask gravity at Twickenham beer festival 2014, light copper with a very thin haze, Seville orange citrus and currant leaf nose, syrupy texture leads to a dry-sweet, fruity toasted marmalade body and a dry-bitter finish. Reminiscent of a hopped up Märzen. Re-rate at JDW, more dry, less sweet and if anything more hoppy and tasty.
Cask @ GBBF 2014. Pours a golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity malty citrus hoppy aroma. Fruity malty citrus hoppy flavor. Has a fruity malty citrus hoppy finish.

Cask at The Royal Oak, Ambleside. Very hopped and strongly fruity. Some citrus, some grapefruit, some toilet disinfectant. Hoppy and delicious - really stood out amongst the plethora of so-so-but-not-outstanding beers on offer.
Cask pint at The Henglers Circus (JDW) in Glasgow. Dark golden colour with a small head.

Cask@ Camperdown place Glasgow
 pours a blonde colour with a white head
 aroma is fruit with grain and hop notes
 taste is sweet with loads of fruit with long dry bitter finish
 Another good beer from this brewery
UPDATED: JAN 1, 2015 An excellent well balanced brew that combines the IPA and ESB styles to great effect.

Cask. Slightly hazy orange, still, small bubbly white head. Aroma is tangerine. Body is medium, smooth, low carbonation. Taste is lightly sweet, herbal and grassy, something reminds me of Indian food, not really bitter at all.
On tap at Cask, Pimlico. Clear golden. Complex spicy hoppiness, also notes of citrus. Good bitterness. Nice.
Pivni in York, Quite dark for an ipa. Hoppy but not as much as some. Very big creamy head. Nice

Pours a clear golden amber with a decent pale buff head. Malty, hoppy aroma has a fruity overtone. Bold, malty flavor is more than the aroma promises, with fruity and subtle greenwood hop notes and a mildly bitter finish. Mouthfeel is tingly and smooth. Hop on over to your nearest package store or bar for one.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2015 500ml bottles served in a small tulip, with revision in June 2015.

Clear medium amber with a small, weak head.

Sweet malts along with a mix of hops in the aroma. 

Under-, or at least low-carbonated, medium-light body. 

English style PA in terms of limited hop flavor and bitterness, and earthy/herbal hops. Hoppy for a ESB

O: Well crafted if rather tame brew.

Cask west riding dewsbury. Light gold colour good white head lacing. Light tropical hop aroma. Taste is sweet tropical fruits great long dry hoppy bitter finish. Medium body. Really good hoppy bitter.
Keg at the Hanging Bat. Sweet, malty toffee, dry, sticky toffee, light fruitiness.

(draught) pours a hazy golden colour with a frothy white head. aroma of tropical fruit and milk chocolate, quite musty and resinous, with a light hint of grain. flavour is more resin and mango, with a hint of banana and a bitter finish. medium-bodied with soft carbonation.

Hazy orange with a thin white head. Crisp fruity nose. Fresh floral flavor, light bodied and clean. Hint of hop finish

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Keg at Pitchers, Stockholm.  Hazy amber, rich head. Rich aroma of ripe pears and mirabelle plums. Mid dry with medium body and rounded, spritzy mouthfeel. Mirabelled, pineapple and hay. Long bitter finish.

Aroma: cereals, hay, sweet hops. Appearance: dark clear gold/light amber, small creamy white head. Taste: light sweet and bitter. Palate: quite heavily carbonated, flowery hops again, sweet notes dry bitter in the average-long finish. Overall: nice ESB, nice sweet aroma. Pint at the Beer Hall, Staveley.

Pours a slightly hazy pale yellow from the cask with minimal white head that doesnt really lace. Aroma is floral hop notes with a hint o pine and biscuit. Taste follows, light and refreshing, easy to drink. A nice English cask ale with nice hop notes.

Botella de 33 cl en noviembre de 2013 del rincón de la cerveza. Esta con lúpulos fuggle (UK) y citra y amarillo (USA) entre otros y con un cuerpo medio de 6 vol. Sabores frescos y amargo final seco y resinoso.
trade with cgarvieuk-Thanks!-12oz bottle-thin white-yellow/gold. A-pine/orange/some lemon, some lt malt. T-sharp pine hops (some citus-orange comes through as it gets to cellar temp), lt malt-bready.

Bottle from Tebay Services, Cumbria. Dark golden pour with a small white head. Decent citrus in the snout. Very tidy hoppage. Dry bitter finish, Really drinkable. Definitely the best Ive tasted from Hawkshead.
Golden with soapy head. Raw, green hop aroma. Flavour of resinous hop, very bitter and dry. Smooth texture.

Cask Pint in Wibbas Down Inn (JDW), Wimbledon in Nov 2013 - Pale Gold in colour. Very Hoppy; grassy and piney hops; nice hop bite. Very Fruity; grapefruit citrus, lemon, tropical fruit. Malty backbone. Bitter (but not too bitter) citrus fruity hoppy throughout. Dry finish. Nice beer!
Bottle from Keswick. Pours golden with small white head. Strong cumquat nose with biscuit. Grapefruit and citrus. Medium body a little oily. Interesting bottle.

On tap at the spoons, Victoria station.
Full malty palate, pepper, grass. As English as they come, to be consumed in big gulps.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2015 1)The Felix, Nuneaton, 23/11/13. Thick malt-heavy gold pillowed with white. Huge tropical aroma with suggestions of guava, lychee, curry leaf, tomato vine and hairy chlorophyll. Mouth fat with condition, mango and leafy goodness. Bittersweet. Some plastic and aniseed. Bitter linger. Deep biscuit. Slightly magnificent. 848416. 
2) The Larry. Burnished gold frilled handsomely. Nose of pine and squashy tropical fruit. Mildly heady tropical fruit over a lean husky base. Bittersweet and perfumed but with some stale tupperwared coconut Im not keen on. Good but disappointing. In fact after a Bishops decidedly average. 
736313
Cask at the William Stead. Amber body. Thin white head. Nose is tangerine and citrus. Tangy and bitter. Dry finish.

Cask at the Old Manor (JDW), Bracknell. Hazy amber with a tight white head; orange marmalade aroma; fruity marmalade taste with a malty body with a touch of caramel; then a crisp, clean, refreshing, grapefruit bitterness to finish. Really good stuff.

[email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ imperial, walsall. Golden beer with medium head and good lacing. Aroma of hops, grapefruit and pineapple. Taste is grapefruit, hops, citrus Orange and a pine resin finish. Very good.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text:
Cask at wetherspoons Brixton. Pours a light amber with a fairly creamy white head. Aroma is some pineapple, mango, lemon. Light body. Peachy, grapes, grapefruit. Nice bitterness. OK. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Cask at Victoria station Spoons, 16/09/13.
Clear pale golden with a thin off white head.
Nose is citrus fruit, orange, hops, light grapefruit notes.
Taste comprises toasted malts, bitter orange, grass, light grapefruit.
Medium bodied, moderate carbonation, hop bitterness in the finish.
Decent stuff.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Keg @ Inn Deep. Hazy amber brown, not much head. Resin fruity malt aroma. Bitter citrus fruit grain & hop flavour, bitter aftertaste. Gets better as it goes down. A good bitter.

Lucid clear orange with fizzy film.of an off white head. Steely sweet nose, citra is burried in here. True golden bittered initial taste, up front hop combo but wasted on a safe coppery bittered platform. Finish is more copper, linger is weird watery meat (reformed ham?)
Bottle, Beets, Leith
Bel dorato buona schiuma piuttosto persistente naso non molto intenso ma complesso agrumato citrico erbaceo floreale leggermente fruttato piuttosto secca ma discreto corpo buon amaro

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; clear amber pour with frothy off white head, aroma is sticky toffee pudding, this had a predominant caramel taste not sure of the bottle age but Im not getting the hops of other reviews, maybe the lupulus had left the bottle, there a slight hint of grapefruit.

Aroma: Earthy with a light white pepper spice. Pear with hints of vine tomato.

Appearance: Hazy golden body with a medium white head. No visible carbonation. Great lacing. 

Taste: Bitter, spicy hops with hints of pear and orange marmalade. Bitter and delicious. 

Palate: Medium body with an oily texture. Light carbonation. 

Overall: A superb, well-hopped Bitter - verging on a Pale Ale.

Bottle from the beer emporium. An absolute cracker. An abundance of fresh fruity hops that is balanced by a smooth dry refreshing finish. Very moorish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ambrata, poca schiuma. Aroma iniziale dolce, fruttato; infine luppolato, resinoso e leggermente agrumato. Al palato ingresso fruttato dolce quasi da caramello, poi come nellaroma interviene il luppolo (mai eccessivo) a equilibrare il tutto, con le sue note agrumate e resinose. Buon equilibrio e freschezza. Una birra piacevole.

Bottle (6%) from Nelson Wines. It pours clear amber with a small white head. The nose is fresh orange, peach, earth, wood, resin and a hint of marzipan. The taste is pithy citrus, orange peel, wood, earth, leather, pepper, resin, touch of alcohol and nice level of bitterness with a dry finish. Nice hop bite to it. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Big bitterness, but remains well balanced. Very nice indeed.

6% bottled version from Cotteridge Wines. This is tasty, strong malts balanced by a lovely hop background. Doesnt have the kick of the big pale ales or the full flavour of anything roasted, but its delicious. I suggested a good plan today for the coming year, I hope that my bosses recognise the value in it.

Plenty of sweet malt on the nose, not a lot of hop.  Pours deep gold with a quickly dissipating head.  The hops come out more in the flavour but the malt is still favoured, and the end result is a little out of balance.  A reasonable dram, but a little confused, and ultimately needs work.
Golden brown pour, resiny, citrus aroma, low carb, full body, bitter finish, nice beer

Cask @The Angel, Manchester (5.Jul.2012)
Deep golden clear body. Hops, honey, sunflowers and grain. Explosion of flavours! Wow! Thanks for sharing, Stefan:-)

Pint at spoons Gateshead. Hazy gold with a white head  Tropical fruit aromas, tropical fruit and grapefruit flavour with a lurking hint of butterscotch. Medium bodied, with quite a bitter finish. Very moreish.
From cask at Counting House. Pours cloudy yellow with a small white head. Aroma is fruity, grapefruity and peachy. Bitter, fruity, grapefruity and peachy. Bitter and citrusy fruity finish.

Cask conditioned at a Wetherspoons. Gold with white head. On the hunt for Fest beers in October managed to bag one of the better beers from an earlier festivals. Sharp, hoppy, dry, bitter, leafy slightly oily hop with a grapefruit pith flavour. Good depth and very tasty, very pleasant.
Bottle from Coppers, Newcastle. Amber coloured with tangerine and orange marmalade fruity flavours, pine bitterness on the finish.clove, clove,

Thanks to fonefan for the bottle as an extra in trade. Clear yellow with a small white head. Aroma is citrus, pine, grapefruit. Light on the palate with a bitter finish. Taste is currants, ruby grapefruit.

Cask (Queens Head, London)
Lovely fruity hoppy bitter. Sticky resiny finish. Very refined. Well attenuated, and easily drinkable for its strength. Very well crafted.

Thx. to the kind soul who shared a 33 cl. bottle of this @ Borefts 2012. Clear pale golden with a white head. Nose is mellower, sweeter hops, are the NZ hops?, caramel, citrus, lighter tropical fruits adding a tad sweeter fruitier juiciness to the whole. Tastes of lychee, mango, sweet flowers, some citrus & touch pine, caramel backbone. Easy to drink - ESB?  You hop any of the blonder beers and then... I dont mind it tastes awesome.

Bottle 330ml. @ [ Edinburgh Danish Invasion Tasting) by cgarvieuk - Edinburgh ].Clear medium amber orange colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is moderate malty, toasted, caramel, moderate to light light heavy hoppy, citrus, orange - citrus, mango. Flavour is moderate to light light heavy sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long to average duration, orange - citrus. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. [20120422]

Cask. Amber, this white head. Nose is citrus fruits, pine. Taste is citrus fruits, hop oils, and strong minerals. Disproportionate amount of hops make it a little rough and cause an unpleasant astringency at the end that brings it down a couple of notches.
Great aroma for a hopped beer, but as far as texture is concerned it is noticeably heavy hopped and not always that pleasant.  Fruit flavours are evident.

Cask at The Moon in the Square, Bournemouth. Now let me firstly say, this is a great ale! A clear medium amber pour with little head and no lace. A really fruity aroma leading to an amazing hop explosion! It had a wonderfully complex set of flavours with a surprisingly smooth edge and citrus notes. The bitterness sits on the palate for a good while longer too. A really special ale which I wish was more widely available.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle.Yellow with a small head. Low carbonation with some citrus. Slightly hoppy and well balanced. The least interesting of this excellent breweries hoppy bears. Still rather nice though.

Bottle from Cotteridge Wines, Birmingham. Dark gold, with marmalade aroma. Taste is pretty rich, with burnt sugar sprinkled over blood orange. Good US hop content and good finish, which is really bitter. Mouthfeel flabby, but otherwise very good.

33cl bottle thanks to unstablefable. Pours a cloudy amber with a thin white head. The nose has pine, lavender and grapefruit - my shower gel. The taste has grapefruit and more grapefruit. The palate is light to medium in body with a zingy finish - slightly too dry for my preference but good for one or two. Overall, a good ale - more like an IPA I think.

Bottle from Drink of Fulham. Deep clear amber with a small, tight head. The nose is Light cut grass, soft grains, subtle malty toffee and some orchard fruits. The taste is pleasant orchard fruits, strawberry, peach. Toasted brown bread with a solid ballasting malt presence. Lightly bitter dry finish. Really pleasing. Medium body, soft light prickly carbonation. Overall, really nice.
Dark blonde with honey and pineapple nose, with big fluffy off-white head. Gentle carbonation, seville marmelade and slight metallic tang in finish.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2016 6/5/12 Slightly cloudy gold ale with white head and lacing. Hops on the nose and grassy. Taste of some sweetness, caramel citrus and hoppyness.
19/3/16 Cask at the Hawkshead Spring Beer Festival.

Pours hazy amber with loose white head. Aroma is lovely; plenty of hops, bubblegummy citrus, and a sweet malt whiff holding it together. Taste is a hint of lemon peel to start, sweet honey, hay, some crystal malt with a lovely bitter finish. Refreshing and drinkable.

Cask conditioned	handpump	The Rake	London	16/05/12.  An amber coloured beer with a whitish head and lacing.  A nice stronger hoppy beer.  The malts tend towards being too sweet and cloying but the hops are good fruity and citrussy.  Nice competent orangey flavours.  The nose is thin.  I expected better as Hawkshead can be very good.
Cask by handpump at Bon Accord, Glasgow (12 May 12) - hazy deep golden ale, medium off-white head, citrus hop aroma, good temperature, very well hopped, citrus, bit soapy, bitter aftertaste.
330ml tomlinsons. aroma: sweet smelling plums. pours: golden, no head. taste: tremendously syrupy, sticky, honey.  A beaut.

Light amber with a creamy lasting white head. Strong smell of citrus hops, malt and fruitiness. Medium thin sticky body. Lasting full hoppy body. Taste of citrus malt, lingering stcky citrus tongue tingle. An excellent hoppy ale. I really enjoyed it.

deep copper orange. thin off white head.
citrus aroma and flavour.  mostly maramalade oranges.
dry hoppy bitter finish. 
good stuff.

bottle.wineways.harrogate
In bottle. Pours a dark golden colour with a fair beige head. Aroma of pine, pineapple, mango and caramel. Similar flavours with a dry finish. Mild carbonation and a foamy mouth-feel. Lovely.

Bottle at cgarvieuks Danish Invasion tasting. Vivid peachy orange colour, bubbly white head that slowly fades to a thick cap. Nice over-the-top dry hop character to the nose, peachy fruits, zesty grapefruit, just a touch of bready malt. Lovely grapefruit hoppy front with a slightly soapy character, just the subtlest hint of caramel malt to balance it out. Long lemony bitter linger. Not bad, but I prefer the NZPA.

Cask at JDW. Golden colour with a creamy white head. Plenty of hops in the aroma, but the taste is where it comes alive. An instant hit of citrus washes away upon layers of bitterness. Goes down really well and keeps you coming back for more. Cracking stuff.
On cask at Hand and Trumpet, Wrinehill.  Pours dark golden with a white head.  As the beer title suggests this is a very hoppy beer.  Low carbonation makes it very drinkable.  Enjoyable.
Cask @ Bon Accord. Golden colour, off-white head. Nose is fruity, grapefruit, pine, dish-cloth. Flavour is malty, grapefruit, dish-cloth, citric. Very well drinkable.

[cask at FyneFest11] Golden pour from the cask at Fyne Ales festival. Enormous fruity nose, the Citra really comes out, but the other hops give their all as well. On the taste, rich passion fruit and floral hop from start to finish. Gets sweet as you go on, but finishes dry. Really very nice indeed. I would class it as a Pale Ale myself, tastes very New World despite the Fuggles and EKGs [11062011]

Cask Handpump at the Postern Gate JDW, York 16/04/2011
Hoppy aroma. White head. Clear golden coloured floral and hoppy with some alcohol present. A hint of bitterness and dryness in a crisp and slightly creamy fruity grapefruit flavoured finish.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2015  Cask at the Rakes Cumbrian Beer Festival. Cloudy orange pour with a white head. Sulphurous nose with a hint of citrus. Citrus tang with some light fruit. Think this one was on the turn. Wouldnt mind having a crack at this when on form.  12/8/2015, GBBF, Olympia, London. Re-rate.. Orange pour with a white head. Citrus and honey aroma leading nicely into the flavour. Crisp bitter fruit finish. Thats more like it! A7/AP3/T7/P3/OV14.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2013 cask at standing order  ...dark amber ... thin white head ... zezty passion fruit citrus nose ... bright fruity hoppy ... again passion fruit ... light lemon zezt ... nice ... 3.9


cask at cloisters 05/12... deep copper ... thin white head ... zezty big hop ... pine and passion fruit nose ... sweet front ... mellow citrus linger ... big fruity hop punch in the middle ... light bitter linger ... soft oily body ... nice ... very hoppy ... but balanced 3.9 

Bottle at home 05/12... golden amber ... bubbly white head ... soft juicy orange and passion fruit ... hint of pine nose ... little fizzy for me ... big passion fruit front ... light oily fruity body ... zezty citrus fruits ... pine and grapefruit ... soft passsion fruit ... very nice but a little too passion fruit for me 4.0

cask at common bar ...June 2013 ... golden amber ... small white head ... sofvt rich juicy floral hop nose ... soft sweet hop... rich soft and juicy ... citrus and summer fruits ... mellow soft easy and oh so drinkable 4.2

Cask at Pilgrims Progress (JDW), Bedford, in Spoons Beer Festival 11, though after the close. Copper with a small white head. Grapefruit hop aroma and taste. Sharp bitter finish. I dont know why I go on buying grapefruity beer. I just dont like it. I know Im going well against the grain here.

Cask, JDW, Carlisle. Another JDW Fest facesaver. This was towards the end of the barrel and had a bit of a haze, otherwise it would have scored even higher. Lovely fresh citrus taste, fruity and very aromatic. So easy to drink, even at 5%, beautifully balanced bitterness and a long lingering finish. Possibly Hawksheads best beer to date?

Cask at The Crosse Keys. Pours a thick, amber-gold with a slight head. Right from the nose you know this is a hoppy sucker. Aroma holds raw hops, pine, grass and earth. Flavor is light to medium sweet with a bit of caramel and bread, but quite bitter with more resinous pine, earth, citrus rind and grass. Medium bodied with fine carbonation. Sticky, hoppy finish, with some mild salt and caramel. Overall a damn solid beer.

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2011 1st April 2011Hamilton Hall Spoons. Very slight haze on this gold beer. Thin white head. Semi dry palate. Good fresh hops. Orange marmalade, a little grassy and a little piney. Citrus. Dry finish with some bitter hops lingering about.14th September 2011On tap at the Craft Beer. Peach and orange in the hops, trace of apricot. Still a 3.5 but a decent beer this. Would be a good sessioner.

Cask at Ruislip Manor WSpoons. Golden coloured pour with a really decent fluffy white head on top. Decent hoppy, tropical fruit aroma. Tastes hoppy (citra, amarillo both evident), nice tropical fruit, malt, slight sweetness. American influenced and really moreish, so drinkable I had 3 pints. Really good stuff, one of the best at this latest JDW fest.

Cask handpull at Knights Templar JDW Chancery Lane.  Last half pint so not expecting much.  Clear gold thin lasting cream head.  Citrus hoppy aroma.  Like satsuma and tangerine and that really small orange fruit with a funny name kumquat?  Very little condition in mouth due to being the last bit out.  But the fullness in the mouth and girgeous hop finish is unmistakeable.  I really is very good.  I have seen Hawkshead as solud their stout is very good and remember drinking that and the bitter in the Ship and Mitre in Liverpool.  And their red ale at Kent BF.  So they clearly make memorable beer.  This could be good but hard to tell in this condition.  Citra is definite as is the Bramling Cross bitterness.  I need this again.  Good though

Hand pulled cask at the Moon under Water (JDW) Watford. When I read the hop line up in the Spoons festival program, I had high hopes for this one, but unlike quite a few promissers from these fests over the years, this one really does what it says on the lable! Gold with a lively white creamy unsparkled head. Good juicy malt coupled with buckets of resinous hops, in a really skillfully blended recipe that Thornbridge, Stone and the likes   would be proud of. The best Spoons Festival beer mixing English and  US hops since Stone/Sheps 2xIPA in 2008. Superb!
